keyTakeAways: A former New York state prison guard, David Kingsley, was found guilty of murder and first-degree manslaughter in the beating death of inmate Robert Brooks.
Two other guards, Mathew Galliher and Nicholas Kieffer, were acquitted of murder charges despite being charged with similar offenses.
The beating of Brooks, captured on silent body-camera footage, revealed guards punishing him multiple times while he was handcuffed, including a fatal attack in the infirmary.
Brooks suffered severe injuries including a broken nose, black eye, and internal organ damage, with blood leaking into his lungs and stomach.
The prosecution argued that all guards acted as a gang with a shared intent to kill, demonstrating a 'depraved indifference to human life'.
The case was led by special prosecutor William Fitzpatrick, who took over due to Attorney General Letitia James’s recusal from representing officers in civil lawsuits.
Fitzpatrick is also prosecuting guards involved in the March 1, 2025, fatal beating of Messiah Nantwi at Mid-State Correctional Facility.
Six of ten guards indicted in February faced murder charges; five previously pleaded guilty to manslaughter, one to a misdemeanor charge of attempted tampering with evidence.
Three more guards have agreed to plead guilty to reduced charges and are cooperating with prosecutors, including two who testified at the trial.
The incident at Marcy Correctional Facility has sparked public outrage over prison violence and the use of body-cameras in documenting misconduct.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A former New York state prison guard, David Kingsley, was found guilty of murder and first-degree manslaughter in the beating death of inmate Robert Brooks, who was violently attacked upon arrival at Marcy Correctional Facility on December 9, 2024. The beating, captured on silent body-camera footage, showed guards repeatedly assaulting Brooks while he was handcuffed, culminating in a fatal attack in the infirmary. While Kingsley was convicted, guards Mathew Galliher and Nicholas Kieffer were acquitted of murder charges, despite being charged with gang assault and other offenses. The prosecution argued that all guards acted together as a gang with a 'depraved indifference to human life.' The case was prosecuted by special prosecutor William Fitzpatrick, who also handles a similar case involving the fatal beating of Messiah Nantwi at Mid-State Correctional Facility. Multiple guards faced charges, with five already pleading guilty to manslaughter and others agreeing to reduced charges or cooperating with prosecutors. The incident has raised public concern over prison violence, guard conduct, and accountability mechanisms within the state’s correctional system.
title: Former New York State Prison Guard Found Guilty in Death of Inmate Beaten, 2 Others Acquitted
